Apple___Apple_scab.description: Apple scab is a common disease of apple and crabapple trees, caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis. It appears as olive-green to brown lesions on leaves and fruit, leading to defoliation and fruit damage.
symptoms: Olive-green to brown spots on leaves
Velvety or fuzzy appearance on lesions
causes: Favored by cool, wet weather in spring
Spreads through water splash and wind
treatment: Apply fungicides (captan, myclobutanil) at first sign of infection
Remove and destroy infected leaves and fruit
Apply fungicide sprays starting at bud break
Use resistant apple varieties when possible
prevention: Rake and destroy fallen leaves in autumn
Plant resistant apple varieties (e.g., Liberty, Enterprise, Freedom)
Ensure good air circulation through proper spacing
Apply preventive fungicide sprays in spring

Apple___Black_rot.description: Black rot is a fungal disease affecting apples, caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa. It causes leaf spot, fruit rot, and limb cankers, potentially devastating apple crops if left untreated.
symptoms: Purple spots on leaves with dark borders
Leaf spots enlarge and turn brown
Fruit develops brown rot starting at blossom end
causes: Spreads through rain splash and wind
treatment: Remove mummified fruit from trees and ground
Prune out infected branches and cankers
Apply fungicides (captan, thiophanate-methyl) during growing season
Maintain tree vigor through proper fertilization
prevention: Remove all mummified fruit before spring

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: Cedar apple rust is a fungal disease requiring two hosts: apple/crabapple trees and cedar trees. It causes distinctive orange spots on apple leaves and fruit.
symptoms: Bright yellow-orange spots on upper leaf surface
causes: Alternates between apple and cedar hosts
Spores released from cedar galls in spring
Wet, humid spring weather favors infection
treatment: Apply fungicides (myclobutanil, propiconazole) at pink bud stage
Continue fungicide applications through early summer
Remove nearby cedar trees if possible
Remove galls from cedar trees in late winter
prevention: Plant resistant apple varieties (e.g., Freedom, Liberty, Enterprise)
Remove cedar trees within 2-4 miles if feasible
Apply preventive fungicides starting at bud break
Maintain tree health through proper care
Monitor and remove cedar galls before spring

Apple___healthy.description: Your apple plant appears healthy! Continue maintaining good care practices to keep your plant disease-free.
treatment: No treatment needed - plant is healthy
prevention: Continue regular monitoring for disease symptoms
Prune regularly for good air circulation

Grape___Black_rot.description: Black rot is one of the most serious diseases of grapes, caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii. It can cause complete crop loss in warm, humid climates.
symptoms: Small tan spots with dark borders on leaves
Infected berries shrivel into hard, black mummies
causes: Overwintering in mummified fruit and canes
treatment: Remove and destroy all mummified berries
prevention: Remove all mummies and debris before spring
Prune vines to improve air circulation
Apply preventive fungicides starting at bud break
Use resistant grape varieties when available

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).description: Esca, also known as Black Measles, is a complex fungal disease affecting grapevines. It's caused by several fungi and can lead to vine decline and death.
symptoms: Tiger-striping pattern on leaves (yellow-green areas between veins)
Dark spots on berries resembling measles
Sudden wilting of shoots or entire vine
causes: Favored by stress and poor vine health
treatment: Prune during dry weather to minimize infection
Maintain vine vigor through proper nutrition
No fully effective chemical control available
prevention: Make pruning cuts during dormancy in dry weather
Apply wound protectants immediately after pruning
Maintain vine health through proper irrigation and nutrition

Grape___healthy.description: Your grape plant appears healthy! Continue maintaining excellent care practices to keep your vines productive and disease-free.
treatment: No treatment needed - plant is healthy
prevention: Clean up fallen leaves and fruit

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.description: Leaf blight, or Isariopsis leaf spot, is a fungal disease that primarily affects grape foliage, causing defoliation and reducing vine vigor.
symptoms: Dark brown to black angular spots on leaves
Most severe on lower, older leaves
causes: Spreads through rain splash and wind
treatment: Apply fungicides (copper-based, mancozeb) at first symptoms
prevention: Prune to open up vine canopy
Apply preventive fungicides in humid conditions
Maintain vine health through proper nutrition

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).description: Huanglongbing (HLB), also called citrus greening, is a devastating bacterial disease spread by Asian citrus psyllids. It has no cure and eventually kills the tree.
symptoms: Yellow shoots and blotchy mottling on leaves
Lopsided, bitter fruit with green ends
causes: Spread by Asian citrus psyllid insects
Also spreads through infected plant material
treatment: Remove and destroy infected trees immediately
Use systemic insecticides on healthy trees
No cure available - management is preventive
prevention: Use only certified disease-free nursery stock
Control Asian citrus psyllid populations aggressively

Peach___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a serious disease of peach trees caused by Xanthomonas bacteria. It affects leaves, fruit, and twigs, reducing yield and fruit quality.
symptoms: Small, angular, water-soaked spots on leaves
Leaf spots turn dark purple to brown
Shot-hole appearance as dead tissue falls out
causes: Spreads through rain splash and wind
Enters through natural openings and wounds
treatment: Prune out infected twigs and branches
prevention: Apply copper sprays in dormant season
Use windbreaks to reduce wind-driven rain
Apply preventive copper sprays before rain

Peach___healthy.description: Your peach plant appears healthy! Keep up the excellent care to maintain tree health and productivity.
treatment: No treatment needed - plant is healthy

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a common fungal disease of potato caused by Alternaria solani. It affects leaves, stems, and tubers, potentially reducing yield significantly.
symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (target pattern) on lower leaves
Progressive upward spread to younger leaves
causes: Spreads through wind and water splash
Survives in plant debris and soil
treatment: Apply fungicides (chlorothalonil, mancozeb) at first symptoms
Ensure proper plant nutrition, especially nitrogen
prevention: Maintain proper plant spacing for air circulation
Apply preventive fungicides before disease appears

Potato___healthy.description: Your potato plant appears healthy! Continue providing excellent care for a bountiful harvest.
treatment: No treatment needed - plant is healthy

Potato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is the most destructive potato disease, caused by Phytophthora infestans. It can destroy entire crops within days under favorable conditions. This is the same pathogen that caused the Irish Potato Famine.
symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves and stems
White fuzzy growth on leaf undersides
causes: Spreads extremely rapidly in cool, wet conditions
Survives in infected tubers and plant debris
treatment: IMMEDIATE action required - apply fungicides urgently
prevention: Apply preventive fungicides before disease appears
Destroy volunteer potato plants and cull piles

Squash___Powdery_mildew.description: Powdery mildew is a common fungal disease affecting squash and other cucurbits. It appears as white powdery patches on leaves and can reduce yield and fruit quality.
symptoms: White powdery patches on upper leaf surfaces
Patches expand and may cover entire leaves
Yellowing and death of infected leaves
causes: Favored by warm days and cool nights
Can develop in both humid and dry conditions
treatment: Organic options: neem oil, milk spray (1:9 milk:water)
prevention: Ensure good air circulation through proper spacing
Water at soil level, avoid wetting foliage
Apply preventive fungicides in susceptible varieties
Remove plant debris at end of season

Strawberry___healthy.description: Your strawberry plant appears healthy! Continue your excellent care practices for sweet, delicious berries.
treatment: No treatment needed - plant is healthy
prevention: Maintain proper spacing for air circulation
Remove runners to maintain plant health

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.description: Leaf scorch is a fungal disease of strawberries caused by Diplocarpon earlianum. It can significantly reduce plant vigor and fruit production if not managed.
symptoms: Small purple to reddish spots on leaves
Spots enlarge and centers turn grayish-white
Spots may merge, giving scorched appearance
treatment: Apply fungicides (captan, myclobutanil) at first symptoms
prevention: Ensure good air circulation through proper spacing
Water at soil level, avoid wetting foliage
Remove old leaves in spring and after harvest
Apply preventive fungicides during wet periods

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a significant disease of tomatoes caused by Xanthomonas bacteria. It affects leaves, stems, and fruit, reducing yield and marketability.
symptoms: Small, dark, greasy-looking spots on leaves
Raised spots on fruit with white halos
causes: Spreads through contaminated seed, transplants, and tools
Water splash and wind-driven rain spread bacteria
treatment: Avoid working with plants when wet
prevention: Use certified disease-free seed and transplants
Rotate crops with non-host plants for 2-3 years
Stake and prune plants for air circulation

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is one of the most common tomato diseases, caused by Alternaria solani fungus. It can significantly reduce yield through defoliation and fruit damage.
symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (target pattern) on lower leaves
Dark, sunken spots on fruit near stem end
causes: Survives in plant debris and soil
treatment: Maintain plant vigor with proper nutrition
prevention: Mulch around plants to reduce splash
Space plants properly for air circulation
Apply preventive fungicides in humid conditions
Remove plant debris at season end

Tomato___healthy.description: Your tomato plant appears healthy! Continue your excellent care for a productive harvest.
treatment: No treatment needed - plant is healthy
prevention: Remove lower leaves as plant grows

Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is the most destructive tomato disease, caused by Phytophthora infestans. It can destroy entire crops within days under favorable conditions.
symptoms: White fuzzy growth on leaf undersides
causes: Spreads extremely rapidly in cool, wet conditions
Wind-blown spores can travel long distances
Survives in infected potato tubers and tomato debris
treatment: Apply fungicides to neighboring plants immediately
prevention: Apply preventive fungicides before disease appears
Remove volunteer tomato and potato plants

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold is a fungal disease primarily affecting greenhouse and high-tunnel tomatoes, caused by Passalora fulva (formerly Cladosporium fulvum).
symptoms: Pale green to yellow spots on upper leaf surface
Olive-green to grayish-purple velvety growth on leaf undersides

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot is a common fungal disease that can cause severe defoliation in tomatoes, reducing yield and exposing fruit to sunscald.
symptoms: Small, circular spots with dark borders on leaves
Tiny black specks (pycnidia) in spot centers
Starts on lower leaves and progresses upward
causes: Survives in plant debris and soil
prevention: Mulch heavily to prevent soil splash
Stake and prune plants for air circulation
Remove lower leaves as plant grows
Apply preventive fungicides in wet weather
Clean up all plant debris at season end

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.description: Two-spotted spider mites are tiny arachnids that feed on tomato plants, causing stippling, yellowing, and potentially severe damage under hot, dry conditions.
symptoms: Fine stippling or speckling on leaves
causes: Favored by hot, dry, dusty conditions
treatment: Spray plants forcefully with water to dislodge mites
Apply insecticidal soap or neem oil
Use miticides (abamectin, bifenazate) for severe infestations
prevention: Monitor regularly, especially in hot weather

Tomato___Target_Spot.description: Target spot is a fungal disease that can cause significant defoliation in tomatoes, particularly in warm, humid climates.
symptoms: Brown spots with concentric rings on leaves
Lesions on fruit near stem end
causes: Spreads through water splash and wind
treatment: Apply fungicides (chlorothalonil, azoxystrobin) at first symptoms
prevention: Remove plant debris at season end
Apply preventive fungicides in humid conditions

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato mosaic virus is a highly contagious viral disease that can significantly reduce tomato yields and fruit quality. It spreads easily through contact.
symptoms: Mottled light and dark green pattern on leaves
Fruit may show mottling or browning
causes: Spreads through contaminated hands, tools, and clothing
Very stable virus survives on surfaces
treatment: NO CURE - remove and destroy infected plants
Disinfect all tools with 10% bleach solution
Avoid tobacco products before handling plants
prevention: Use certified disease-free seed and transplants
Avoid smoking near plants (tobacco carries related virus)
Control aphids which may spread virus

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV) is a devastating viral disease spread by whiteflies. It can cause severe yield losses, especially in warm climates.
symptoms: Yellowing and upward curling of leaves
Leaf margins curl upward forming cup shape
causes: Spread exclusively by silverleaf whitefly (Bemisia tabaci)
Whiteflies acquire virus by feeding on infected plants
Warm climates favor both virus and whitefly
treatment: NO CURE - remove and destroy infected plants
Apply reflective mulches to repel whiteflies
Use insecticidal soap or neem oil
prevention: Control whiteflies with yellow sticky traps
Plant early to avoid peak whitefly populations
